title: How to Make Turkey Bean Chili

steps.headline: Dice 14.5 ounces (410 g) of tomatoes.
steps.description: Wash 4 medium tomatoes in cold water and remove all stickers from them. Afterward, use a serrated or straight-edged kitchen knife to cut them into equally thick slices. Stack the slices on top of each other or lay them flat beside each other. Now, cut them into strips, and then cut the strips into equal sized dice. Hold the top of your knife steady with your non-dominant hand. For small diced tomatoes, cut the slices close together. For thicker dice, cut them farther apart. Purchase canned diced tomatoes to skip this step.

steps.headline: Cut 1 poblano pepper into 1/3 cup (39.3 grams).
steps.description: Start by placing the poblano pepper onto a cutting board horizontally. Now, make a horizontal cut to create 2 equally sized halves. Afterward, align the pieces vertically in front of you—skin-side down—and cut them in half into long strips about 0.5 to 1 inch (1.3 to 2.5 cm) wide. Keep your knuckles closest to the tip of the knife blade as you cut. Press each piece of poblano pepper flat to make it easier to cut them.

steps.headline: Chop 1 cup (150 grams) of red onions.
steps.description: Start by slicing the top of the onion and then place it onto its cut end. Now, cut it in half vertically and lay 1 half onto the cutting board so that the root faces away from you. Hold the root end with your non-dominant hand and make vertical cuts through it. Afterward, rotate the onion 90 degrees and continue making repeated vertical cuts that are perpendicular to the first cuts. Repeat the above process for the other onion half. Always remove the onion's skin before cutting. Don't cut all the way through the onion during the first round of cuts. Always leave the root end intact and only separate the pieces completely during the final perpendicular cuts. Keep all cuts about ⁄4 inch (0.64 cm) apart and parallel.

steps.headline: Rinse and drain a 19 ounce (540 g) can of cannellini beans.
steps.description: Pour your can of beans into a strainer and put it in the sink. Run them under cold water and move the strainer in quick circles while using your dominant hand to mix them around. Afterward, let the strainer sit in the sink for a few minutes. Continue rinsing your tomatoes until no bean juice comes out the bottom of the strainer.

steps.headline: Heat your red onion, poblano pepper, minced garlic, and ground turkey on medium.
steps.description: Put your 1 cup (150 grams) of prechopped red onion, 1/3 cup (39.3 grams) of chopped and seeded poblano pepper, 1 teaspoon (2.80 grams) of bottled and minced garlic, and 1.25 pounds (0.57 kg) of ground turkey in a large saucepan on medium heat. Continue cooking them for 6 minutes or until the turkey is cooked. Stir the mixture often to ensure it creates a crumble.

steps.headline: Add the remaining ingredients save for cilantro and boil.
steps.description: Pour in your 1 tablespoon (8.12 grams) of chili powder, 2 tablespoons(33.22 grams) of tomato paste, 2 teaspoons (6.08 grams) of dried oregano, 1 teaspoon (2.1 grams) of ground cumin, 1/4 teaspoon (1.42 grams) of salt, 1/4 teaspoon (0.575 grams) of black pepper, 19 ounce (540 g) can of cannellini beans, 14.5 ounces (410 g) of diced tomatoes, and 14 ounce (400 g) can of fat-free, lower-sodium chicken broth. Once you're done adding ingredients, increase the heat to high and bring your saucepan to a boil. Keep stirring the ingredients through the process. When you notice fast, rapid bubbles rising to the surface continuously, the mixture is boiling.

steps.headline: Simmer your chili for 10 minutes.
steps.description: Once the chili starts to boil, decrease the heat and let it simmer. Continue letting it simmer for 10 minutes. Your mixture is simmering when a small bubble or 2 breaks the surface of the chili every 1 to 2 seconds.

steps.headline: Chop and add 1/2 cup (25 grams) of fresh cilantro.
steps.description: Start by cutting or twisting off the stems from the bottom of your cilantro bunch. Now, chop your cilantro by applying light pressure in quick, downward strokes as you move your knife around the cutting board. Continue chopping your cilantro until each piece is a size to your liking and add them to your chili. Hold the top of the knife with your non-dominant hand to guide the knife. Don't use a dull knife or you will crush the cilantro as you chop it, which will cause it to disintegrate. Pick off individual leaves instead of chopping if you'd like. However, this is a lot more time-consuming.

steps.headline: Stir in your cilantro for 1 to 2 minutes and serve.
steps.description: Stir your fresh cilantro into the chili as it simmers. Continue mixing it in for 1 to 2 minutes and then it's ready to serve! If you're not a fan of cilantro, decrease the amount or remove it altogether. Swap your cilantro with tarragon, dill, parsley, or any combination of each. Try pairing your chili with buttermilk cornbread, french fries, cornbread, grilled cheese, or fried pickles.

text: Chopping Your Vegetables and Turkey Dice 14.5 ounces (410 g) of tomatoes. Wash 4 medium tomatoes in cold water and remove all stickers from them. Afterward, use a serrated or straight-edged kitchen knife to cut them into equally thick slices. Stack the slices on top of each other or lay them flat beside each other. Now, cut them into strips, and then cut the strips into equal sized dice. Hold the top of your knife steady with your non-dominant hand. For small diced tomatoes, cut the slices close together. For thicker dice, cut them farther apart. Purchase canned diced tomatoes to skip this step. Cut 1 poblano pepper into 1/3 cup (39.3 grams). Start by placing the poblano pepper onto a cutting board horizontally. Now, make a horizontal cut to create 2 equally sized halves. Afterward, align the pieces vertically in front of you—skin-side down—and cut them in half into long strips about 0.5 to 1 inch (1.3 to 2.5 cm) wide. Keep your knuckles closest to the tip of the knife blade as you cut. Press each piece of poblano pepper flat to make it easier to cut them. Chop 1 cup (150 grams) of red onions. Start by slicing the top of the onion and then place it onto its cut end. Now, cut it in half vertically and lay 1 half onto the cutting board so that the root faces away from you. Hold the root end with your non-dominant hand and make vertical cuts through it. Afterward, rotate the onion 90 degrees and continue making repeated vertical cuts that are perpendicular to the first cuts. Repeat the above process for the other onion half. Always remove the onion's skin before cutting. Don't cut all the way through the onion during the first round of cuts. Always leave the root end intact and only separate the pieces completely during the final perpendicular cuts. Keep all cuts about ⁄4 inch (0.64 cm) apart and parallel. Rinse and drain a 19 ounce (540 g) can of cannellini beans. Pour your can of beans into a strainer and put it in the sink. Run them under cold water and move the strainer in quick circles while using your dominant hand to mix them around. Afterward, let the strainer sit in the sink for a few minutes. Continue rinsing your tomatoes until no bean juice comes out the bottom of the strainer. Cooking Your Chili Heat your red onion, poblano pepper, minced garlic, and ground turkey on medium. Put your 1 cup (150 grams) of prechopped red onion, 1/3 cup (39.3 grams) of chopped and seeded poblano pepper, 1 teaspoon (2.80 grams) of bottled and minced garlic, and 1.25 pounds (0.57 kg) of ground turkey in a large saucepan on medium heat. Continue cooking them for 6 minutes or until the turkey is cooked. Stir the mixture often to ensure it creates a crumble. Add the remaining ingredients save for cilantro and boil. Pour in your 1 tablespoon (8.12 grams) of chili powder, 2 tablespoons(33.22 grams) of tomato paste, 2 teaspoons (6.08 grams) of dried oregano, 1 teaspoon (2.1 grams) of ground cumin, 1/4 teaspoon (1.42 grams) of salt, 1/4 teaspoon (0.575 grams) of black pepper, 19 ounce (540 g) can of cannellini beans, 14.5 ounces (410 g) of diced tomatoes, and 14 ounce (400 g) can of fat-free, lower-sodium chicken broth. Once you're done adding ingredients, increase the heat to high and bring your saucepan to a boil. Keep stirring the ingredients through the process. When you notice fast, rapid bubbles rising to the surface continuously, the mixture is boiling. Simmer your chili for 10 minutes. Once the chili starts to boil, decrease the heat and let it simmer. Continue letting it simmer for 10 minutes. Your mixture is simmering when a small bubble or 2 breaks the surface of the chili every 1 to 2 seconds. Chop and add 1/2 cup (25 grams) of fresh cilantro. Start by cutting or twisting off the stems from the bottom of your cilantro bunch. Now, chop your cilantro by applying light pressure in quick, downward strokes as you move your knife around the cutting board. Continue chopping your cilantro until each piece is a size to your liking and add them to your chili. Hold the top of the knife with your non-dominant hand to guide the knife. Don't use a dull knife or you will crush the cilantro as you chop it, which will cause it to disintegrate. Pick off individual leaves instead of chopping if you'd like. However, this is a lot more time-consuming. Stir in your cilantro for 1 to 2 minutes and serve. Stir your fresh cilantro into the chili as it simmers. Continue mixing it in for 1 to 2 minutes and then it's ready to serve! If you're not a fan of cilantro, decrease the amount or remove it altogether. Swap your cilantro with tarragon, dill, parsley, or any combination of each. Try pairing your chili with buttermilk cornbread, french fries, cornbread, grilled cheese, or fried pickles.
